title: 111_hr230
content: The Act may be cited as the "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009" and includes provisions for affordable refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation are required to carry out a program to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages on single-family housing. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency will establish policies and procedures for this program. If a lender offers a mortgage for purchase under this program, the enterprise will determine whether to purchase it. The enterprise must determine if a mortgage qualifies as a qualified mortgage and if so, commit to purchasing it. The Director will require each enterprise to establish a procedure for approving lenders to receive advance commitments for the purchase of qualified mortgages. Qualified mortgages are defined as either qualified refinancing mortgages or qualified new mortgages. A qualified refinancing mortgage must be for a one to four-family dwelling, including condominiums or cooperative ownership housing associations. The mortgagor must occupy the property as their principal residence and use the loan amount to pay off existing indebtedness on the same property. The mortgage must be for refinancing, originated on or before January 1, 2008, with a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually, and a term of 30-40 years from the beginning of amortization. The qualified new mortgage must meet underwriting standards set by the Director and have all prepayment penalties and fees waived. The mortgage for a qualified new mortgage must meet specific requirements, including terms, home purchase use, and origination date. Enterprises can establish exceptions to underwriting standards. Enterprises can establish exceptions to underwriting standards to allow the purchase and securitization of qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. Each enterprise must set aside qualified mortgages and issue securities upon approval of the Secretary of the Treasury. Securities issued by enterprises under this subsection may be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates of beneficial interest, with maturities and interest rates determined by the enterprise with approval from the Secretary of the Treasury. These securities are exempt to the same extent as direct obligations or guaranteed obligations. Securities issued by enterprises under this subsection, whether in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates, are considered exempt securities guaranteed by the United States. Mortgages set aside must always be sufficient to cover timely payments on the securities. Each enterprise must include appropriate disclosure language in all issued securities. The Federal Reserve will establish a credit facility to provide credit to enterprises at interest rates similar to Treasury securities. Securities issued by enterprises are not guaranteed by the United States and do not constitute a debt of the government. The Federal Reserve will establish a credit facility for enterprises to access credit at rates similar to Treasury securities. Enterprises are not required to purchase mortgages after December 31, 2010. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as Director, Enterprise, and Secretary. The Director refers to the head of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, while Enterprise includes the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The Secretary mentioned is the Secretary of the Treasury.
